div.head: Summary
div.p: The Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra is a short work that provides two dhāraṇīs that are meant to complement the practice of recollecting the Buddha (buddhānusmṛti). The work also provides a set of correspondences between the ornaments associated with Śākyamuni’s sambhogakāya form and the enlightened qualities and powers that one gains on the bodhisattva path.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: Translated by the Dharmachakra Translation Committee under the supervision of Chökyi Nyima Rinpoche. The translation was produced by Adam Krug and then checked against the Tibetan and edited by Ryan Damron.

The Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra Skt. Ārya­buddha­hṛdaya­nāma­dhāraṇī­dharma­paryāya. viparyaya] D 514; viparyāya] D 854; paryāya] S. The Sanskrit transliteration viparyāya in the Degé for the Tibetan term rnam grangs contains an unnecessary prefix. The proper Sanskrit for the Tibetan rnam grangs is simply paryāya, which is preserved in the Stok Palace Kangyur. opens with the Buddha and an assembly of bodhisattvas residing in a hermitage in the celestial realm Universal Radiance. The Buddha begins by telling the assembly that The Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra has been taught by all the buddhas of the past and then outlines the various benefits one accrues by reciting the mantra. He then recites two dhāraṇīs, causing the earth and the oceans to tremble and inciting panic in Māra’s realm.

The instructions in this text contain a set of symbolic correspondences between the ornaments of Śākyamuni’s sambhogakāya form and the various powers attained by buddhas and bodhisattvas. The eight ornaments and their related significances are as follows:

item.p: 2. Long necklace (investigation of all one has studied)
4. Scented powders (knowing the full range of beings’ capacities)
5. Ointments (understanding each of the teachings one has studied and internalized correctly and discriminating among them)
6. Clothing (non-apprehension of phenomena in order to bring all beings to ultimate fruition)
7. Jewelry (skill in methods due to the Buddha’s blessing)

div.p: After layering this set of eight ornaments associated with Śākyamuni’s sambhogakāya form with eight aspects of the practice and accomplishment of the bodhisattva path, the text concludes with instructions to recite the Buddha’s heart mantras while performing the practice of recollecting the Buddha.

The translators’ colophon notes that this text was translated by the Indian paṇḍitas Jinamitra and Dānaśīla along with the Tibetan translator Bandé Yeshé Dé (c. eighth century). The text appears in the Phangthangma dkar chag ’phang thang ma (2003), 26. royal Tibetan catalogue of translated works among the collection of various dhāraṇī, but locating the text in the Denkarma royal Tibetan catalogue is a bit problematic. The Denkarma’s collection of dhāraṇī contains two texts titled The Buddha’s Heart Mantra (’phags pa sangs rgyas kyi snying po), Yoshimura (1950), 151; 152. neither of which matches the full title of the present work. This double listing likely preserves a record of the present text and another text with a similar title, The Dhāraṇī of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra (’phags pa sangs rgyas kyi snying po zhes bya ba’i gzungs), that appear alongside each other in the Degé Kangyur in The Tantra Collection (rgyud ’bum) and The Compendium of Incantations (gzungs ’dus). Both of the dhāraṇī mantras in this text are included in Butön’s Collection of Dhāraṇī of the Four Classes of Secret Mantra (gsang sngags rgyud sde bzhi’i gzungs ’bum). Butön Rinchen Drup (1965–1971), folio 247.a.

The text was translated into Chinese in 650 ce by Hsüan-tsang (T. 918), 玄奘 Xuanzang. For more information on this figure, see Lewis R. Lancaster, “K 444,” The Korean Buddhist Canon, accessed November 16, 2018, http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/files/k0444.html. and again in the late tenth century by Fa-t’ien (T. 919). 法天 Fatian. For more information on this figure, see Lewis R. Lancaster, “K 1134,” The Korean Buddhist Canon, accessed November 16, 2018, http://www.acmuller.net/descriptive_catalogue/files/k1134.html. The Peking Imperial Palace catalogue lists two Sanskrit works, Peking Imperial Palace STP 9.2519; 11.3497. but these sources were unfortunately not available to be consulted for this translation. A complete list of all the Sanskrit, Chinese, and Tibetan sources can be accessed at The Buddhist Canons Research Database: http://databases.aibs.columbia.edu/index.php.

This translation is primarily based on the Tibetan translations of the text from the Tantra Collection and the Compendium of IncantationsThis latter text, Toh 854, and all those contained in the same volume (gzungs ’dus, e), are listed as being located in volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur by the Buddhist Digital Resource Center (BDRC). However, several other Kangyur databases—including the eKangyur that supplies the digital input version displayed by 84000 reading room—list this work as being located in volume 101. This discrepancy is partly due to the fact that the two volumes of the gzungs ’dus section are an added supplement not mentioned in the original catalogue, and also hinges on the fact that the compilers of the Tōhoku catalogue placed another text—which forms a whole, very large volume—the Vimala­prabhā­nāma­kālacakra­tantraṭīkā (dus ’khor ’grel bshad dri med ’od, Toh 845), before the volume 100 of the Degé Kangyur, numbering it as vol. 100, although it is almost certainly intended to come right at the end of the Degé Kangyur texts as volume 102; indeed its final fifth chapter is often carried over and wrapped in the same volume as the Kangyur dkar chags (catalogue). Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Thus did I hear at one time. The Blessed One was residing and teaching the Dharma within the palace called Universal Radiance—a secluded Dharma hermitage chos kyi g.ye dgon pa] D 854; chos kyi dbye/ dgon pa] D 514; chos kyi dbye dgon pa] S. with a courtyard arrayed with jewels that is the home of the thus-gone ones, a place where gnosis is perfectly analyzed, a place blessed by the buddhas of the past and praised by all beings, an abode of the great bodhisattvas who possess the most supreme of all mental images, Tibetan: rnam pa thams cad kyi mchog dang ldang pa. The phrase is a translation of the Sanskrit sarvākāravaropeta, which in some cases can translate as “endowed with the best of all aspects.” In this case, however, the term sarvākāravara signifies the object of perception for awakened beings in which the term rnam pa/ākāra carries its epistemological significance as the mental image that is presented (or in the case of the perception of awakened beings, spontaneously appears) to the mind. This is the meaning of the term that is intended in the famous visualization sequence of the pañcākārabhisambodhi­krama that provides the foundational structure for the yoga of the Yogatantra. In the current context, it makes sense that the term is being used to describe the level that a “great bodhisattva” has reached in which the only remaining episteme is the “most supreme of all mental images,” or the nature of reality itself. and a place that is in harmony with the sameness of all phenomena. He was surrounded and venerated by billions of bodhisattvas, all of whom had been prophesied to become buddhas, had assembled from their separate world systems, thams cad kyan lun bstan pa/ thams cad kyang ’jig rten gyi khams tha dad pa nas ’dus pa] D 854; ’jig rten gyi khams tha dad pa nas lung stan pa/ thams cad kyang ’jig rten gyi khams tha dad pa nas ’dus pa] D 514, S. D 514 and S appear to unnecessarily repeat the phrase ’jig rten gyi khams tha dad pa nas. This translation follows D 854. were the heirs of the thus-gone ones who are the kings of the Dharma, and had attained the various dhāraṇīs and absorptions.

The Blessed One addressed the great assembly of bodhisattvas, saying, “Sons of the lineage, The Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra has been taught by as many thus-gone, worthy, perfect complete buddhas as there are sands in the river Ganges in order to benefit many beings, to bring happiness to many beings, to express sincere love for the world, and to benefit, help, and bring happiness to the great multitude of gods and humans. If sons or daughters of the lineage receive this Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra, bear it in mind, recite it, master it, teach it correctly and extensively to others, have faith in it, or generate exceptional devotion toward it, they will never revert from unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening. They will never lack an understanding of all phenomena. They will never part company with the blessed buddhas. They will see the Thus-Gone One, and they will never be without attendants, Dharma students, or those who revere the saṅgha. They will plumb the farthest depths of the ocean of saṃsāra for a thousand eons. They will remember their past lives leading up to becoming buddhas who have completely manifested unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening. They will quickly become buddhas who have completely manifested unsurpassed, perfect, complete awakening. All the hordes of spirit beings will protect them. All human and nonhuman beings such as gods, nāgas, yakṣas, gandharvas, asuras, garuḍas, kinnaras, and mahoragas will be fond of them. Their bodies will not be afflicted by illness. They will be invincible to those who would do them harm. They will be impervious to clubs and swords, will neutralize poisons, and will not suffer unnatural deaths. They will no longer be assaulted by the evil Māra or harassed by the deities of Māra’s horde. When they direct their attention at them, all the deities of Māra’s horde will tremble, panic in fear, and scatter in the ten directions.
“These are the Buddha’s words, the Buddha’s great words, the great words that were given by the Buddha, the words of all buddhas, the words of all the thus-gone ones:

div.p: “Although the objects that the Buddha perceives and the Dharma that he has taught are infinite, the simplified instruction is that one should focus the mind on a single thing. gcig tu yid la bya ba ni mdor na sgom pa’o] D 854; gcig tu yid la bya ba ni mdor na chos sgom pa’o] D 524; gcig tu yid la bya ba ni mdor na chos bsgom pa’o] S.
“The following dhāraṇī has been taught by all the buddhas out of their sincere love for all beings. It is the seal of all qualities:

tadyathā śuddhe suśuddhe suśuddhe śodhani saṁśodhani saṁśodhani nirmale malāpagate gate gati] D 854, S; gate] D 514. samatikranti samatikranti] D 854; samātikranti] D 514; samādhitanti] S. krame samasare sarāsaraparyāśoke viśoka śokaśamani śānte upaśānte praśānte avabhāse sarvapunye parimaṇḍite parimaṇḍite] D 854, S; parimiṇḍite] D 514. sarva­dharma­pratimaṇḍite hara hara mala hara cara cara saṁcara cala cala saṁcala tala tala matala samatala riṇe riṇe suriṇe samariṇe riṇamati­loka­dhare loka­dhariṇe dhara dhara ḍara ḍara rodha rodha mahāvijaya vāhini hana hana sarva­buddhe hriphreṣi trasi sarva­jñāpathe sarva­jñāpāramite mahā­pratibhāna­saṃpanne mahā­pratibhāna­saṃpanne] D 514; mahā­pratibhāna­saṃphanne] D 854; mahā­pratibhana­saṃpanne] S. samantāloke buddhe viṣaye buddha­pratimaṇḍite bhagavate sara sara prasara prasara visara visara prasara sarva­śokāpagate svāhā.”

As soon as the Blessed One had spoken this Dhāraṇī Discourse of the Buddha’s Heart Mantra, the mountain, the surrounding area, and the forest shook in the following six ways: the three-thousand-fold universe shook, shook violently, and shook all over. The great ocean trembled, trembled violently, and trembled all over. The supreme king of mountains trembled and quaked. The entire abode of Māra was terrified, and all of the deities of Māra’s horde and the wicked Māras were extremely distressed and miserable.

The beings who witnessed the great earth quaking prostrated to the thus-gone, arhat, perfect and complete buddha and recited the phrase “I prostrate to the thus-gone, arhat, perfect and complete buddha” three times. The gods that had genuine faith mngon par dad pa] D 514, S; mnon par dang ba] D 854. in the Buddha showered the Blessed One with divine mandārava flowers and great mandārava flowers, and by showering him with flowers brought joy to all who sought refuge in the Buddha. And thus it was said that:

lg.l: “When the lion of the Śākya clan,
The perfect, complete buddha and our refuge,
The ocean trembled, all of Māra’s realm
Shook violently, and the deities of Māra’s horde
“While the māras were overcome with sorrow and misery,
And rained mandārava flowers from the sky
As an offering to the world protector.
“Others who had true faith mngon dad] D 854, S; dang] D 514. in the Buddha
Made offerings of short and long necklaces,

div.p:
“These eight offerings became the ornaments that symbolize the beneficial advantages of his good qualities. The eight symbolic ornaments are enumerated as follows: (1) the ornament that symbolizes not forgetting bodhicitta; (2) the ornament symbolizing insatiable investigation of all one has studied; (3) the ornament that symbolizes dependent origination, the definitive understanding of the profound Dharma; (4) the ornament symbolizing knowing
the full range of all beings’ capacities; (5) the ornament that symbolizes understanding each of the teachings one has studied and internalized correctly and discriminating among them; (6) the ornament that symbolizes the non-apprehension of phenomena in order to bring all beings to ultimate fruition; (7) the ornament symbolizing skill in methods due to the Buddha’s blessing; and (8) the ornament of obtaining dhāraṇīs. Those eight are the ornaments that symbolize the beneficial advantages of his good qualities.

“All beings should continually contemplate this dhāraṇī and meditate while recollecting the Buddha. If they contemplate this root dhāraṇī, all their karmic obscurations will be purified, they will attain the meditative concentration called the lotus array, and they will be able to wash away all illnesses and diseases with their hands. They should perform innumerable recitations of this dhāraṇī.”
When the Blessed One had said this the bodhisattva great beings, great śrāvakas, and the entire world with its gods, humans, asuras, and gandharvas praised the Blessed One’s words.
div.trailer: This concludes the noble dhāraṇī discourse “The Buddha’s Heart Mantra.”

div.head: Colophon
div.p: This work was translated and edited by the Indian teachers Jinamitra and Dānaśīla along with the chief editor and translator Bandé Yeshé Dé. It was later revised according to the new language reform and then finalized. The version in the Stok Palace Kangyur does not include a translators’ colophon.
